question: What is the role of a frozen section in cancer surgeries?
answer:
The role of a frozen section in cancer surgeries is to provide quick and accurate diagnosis during the surgical procedure. Frozen sections allow surgeons to examine the tissue under a microscope shortly after it is removed, enabling them to determine whether the tissue is cancerous and how much of the surrounding tissue needs to be removed to ensure complete resection of the cancer. (Source: "Frozen Section Processing" from LabCE.com)

question: How are sentinel lymph nodes analyzed in pathology?
answer: Sentinel lymph nodes are analyzed in pathology through a combination of histopathology and immunohistochemistry. question: What is the role of artificial intelligence in modern cancer pathology?
answer:
The role of artificial intelligence in modern cancer pathology is to predict a patient's response to certain anti-cancer therapy based on their own genetic make-up, and to analyze and interpret pathology-related information for personalized medicine. Additionally, artificial intelligence has the potential to diagnose and classify human tumors, design and validate predictive biomarkers, and predict microsatellite instability directly from histology. These advancements are possible due to the development of deep learning and other AI technologies (U.P. et al., 2019; Lin et al., 2015).

Source: U.P. et al. (2019). Deep learning can predict microsatellite instability directly from histology in gastrointestinal cancer. Nat. Med. 25, 1054 -1056.

question: What are the differences between ductal and lobular breast carcinoma in pathology?
answer:
According to the American Cancer Society, ductal carcinoma is the most common type of breast cancer, accounting for about 80% of all breast cancers, while lobular carcinoma accounts for about 10-15% (https://www.cancer.org/cancer/breast-cancer/about/how-it-starts.html).

The main difference between ductal and lobular breast carcinoma lies in their location and behavior. Ductal carcinoma arises in the milk ducts, while lobular carcinoma arises in the lobules of the breast. Lobular carcinoma is often more aggressive and tends to spread to other parts of the body more quickly than ductal carcinoma.

It is important to note that both types of breast cancer can be treated effectively if caught early, and that lumpiness, changes in breast size or shape, and nipple retraction are common symptoms of both types of cancer.
